Situation1: Their partner is going through a serious personal crisis and relies on them for consistent emotional reassurance and presence.
Expectation2: Attend daily prayers and religious services
Situation2: A special healing service is being held for a sick member of the community, which is outside of the usual schedule.
Story: I sat at the edge of our bed, my husband’s hand trembling in mine. His eyes, red from sleepless nights, searched my face for comfort. He needed me—needed my words, my touch, my unwavering presence as he faced the darkest days of his life. I wanted nothing more than to stay, to hold him, to reassure him that he wasn’t alone. But the bell from the chapel echoed through the halls, a reminder of my other life. Tonight, the sisters were gathering for a special healing service, praying for Sister Agnes, who had fallen gravely ill. My absence would be noticed; my commitment to the community questioned. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing down on me—my vows as a wife pulling me one way, my vows as a nun pulling me another. My heart ached with the impossibility of being fully present in both places, for both people who needed me. I closed my eyes, torn, as the chapel bell rang again.
